haiku.text:
We are seeing that an economy based on the exploitation of natural resources
is like extracting the bones and blood of human beings or looting the scalp, which is irreplaceable.
haiku.caption: - Luis Delgado, community organizer

haiku.text: We are well aware the Mother Earth is another living being like us.
haiku.caption: - Sandra Delgado, community organizer

haiku.text:
By using a variety of native plants to build, clean and retain the soil
we have seen that ecological restoration can be accomplished in as little as 10 years.
haiku.caption: - Dr. Percy Nunez, Andean biologist

haiku.text:
We used to have 400 different species of trees in the valley of Cusco,
many parts of the Andes were evergreen, but now we only have a few dozen tree species left.
haiku.caption: - Dr. Percy Nunez, Andean biologist

haiku.text:
From the moment I took my first steps in life,
I realized I had to pass on the culture of my ancestors. I have tried to
evoke the concept of respecting all biodiversity which is so paramount in the high Andes.
haiku.caption: - Luis Delgado, community organizer

haiku.text:
We have been teaching at schools with biologists,
teaching children how to take care of the lakes, plants, and animals.
We have little support so it is difficult, but the children are starting to teach their elders at home.
haiku.caption: - Sandra Delgado, community organizer

haiku.text:
Young people go to Lima. Why this migration? They leave due to lack of opportunities.
One of the reasons is the lack of water. Now we can’t have big farming areas and even cattle is greatly reduced.
haiku.caption: -Ferrero Jimenez de la Rosa, President of Huamantanga

haiku.text:
Humans think money is everything. We know this is not right.
When the earth gives no more, and you can’t plant anything, are they going to eat their money?
haiku.caption: - Sandra Delgado, community organizer

haiku.text:
Many people believe that development only comes from economic gain.
This thinking causes irreversible damage because it is wrong, you cannot buy nature.
Our consciousness has to evolve, it is on this type of development that humanity depends.
haiku.caption: - Luis Delgado, community organizer

haiku.text:
Forests have been pillaged.
The mountains are losing their perennial snow.
In 20 years we will have conflicts over the water.
haiku.caption: - Sandra Delgado, community organizer

haiku.text:
That’s why we are planting trees,
to take care of the lakes,
but we are too few doing this.
haiku.caption: - Sandra Delgado, community organizer

haiku.text:
We need to work, we need to become conscious,
we need to transmit the knowledge of our ancestors
and all the people that are interested can help me with this purpose.
haiku.caption: - Luis Delgado, community organizer

haiku.text:
I will tell you about my community. From 1960 to 1980, there was too
much winter and plenty of water, then from1990 on we had a drought that
lasted for 3 years. After that, the winters left and they never were the same again.
haiku.caption: - Ferrero Jimenez de la Rosa, President of Huamantanga

haiku.text: If these problems don’t get sorted, this will soon be a ghost town.
haiku.caption: - Ferrero Jimenez de la Rosa, President of Huamantanga

haiku.text:
The ancient ones were the first astrologers and geologists,
the first farmers and technicians, and they left us a whole irrigation system
built with infiltration channels. There was a culture of tribute to water, that we have to recover.
haiku.caption: - Speaker, canal revitalization ceremony

haiku.text:
Then plastic technology and plastic culture came overnight.
Nowadays, everything that we buy is in a plastic bag and the water is being poisoned with trash.
haiku.caption: - Luis Delgado, community organizer

haiku.text:
At the Circuit of the Four Lakes we have done an environmental
treatment, but this is like a small point on your body and we are talking about the earth.
haiku.caption: - Luis Delgado, community organizer

haiku.text:
We do this work because we like to reward our Mother Earth because she
feeds us and she nourishes all human beings. We are very few, but we do it with great heart.
haiku.caption: - Sandra Delgado, community organizer

haiku.text:
500 years ago we Incans had a strong clash, a cultural clash.
Our indigenous culture almost vanished completely. Since then we
have been overshadowed by becoming more and more indifferent to nature.
haiku.caption: - Luis Delgado, community organizer

haiku.text:
Traditional knowledge is, for example,
the ceremony for mother earth. It’s a small compensation that is done twice a year.
haiku.caption: - Sandra Delgado, community organizer

haiku.text:
The indigenous cultures of the Americas, from Alaska to Patagonia, are cultures
that respect their circular area, their biodiversity. It shows that we still have certain understanding
of nature to this day. We are trying to protect and restore the land, the few of us who still identify with nature.
haiku.caption: - Luis Delgado, community organizer

haiku.text:
What we need to learn now is to coexist with nature.
We now have extreme environmental pollution and global warming.
This is a warning, and it has been foreseen that water is going to extinguish.
haiku.caption: - Huamantanga community leader, canal revitalization ceremony

haiku.text:
We are not going to believe this because we have the ability
to conserve and store our water. Today we have to re-encounter the
landscape and I think it is our task to teach young people to return to nature and water.
haiku.caption: -Huamantanga community leader, canal revitalization ceremony

haiku.text:
I congratulate you for the recovery of these canal systems and
tribute ceremonies. That are very important not only for this community, but since these
waters reach the sea, they bathe many lands down to the shore and provide many other villages with water.
haiku.caption: - Speaker, canal revitalization ceremony

intro.text:
Water.2.5 Water is everything.2.5

Feel it running through your veins. For a brief second 2.5 imagine thirst.2.5

The world is beginning to dry, it is time to act.2.5

Resilience is a new media documentary that weaves community-based watershed restoration stories together.

Beginning with two watersheds in the remote Peruvian Andes, this project is an ongoing effort.

The Resilience interactive interface acts as a loom that creates a fabric out of a collection of short films (2 minutes or less) and photographic haiku.

This content is organized along different conceptual threads and the viewer can weave these threads together to create different patterns in the story fabric.

These patterns can shift and adapt, akin to a living system.

As unique story patterns emerge, previously unseen connections can be made.2.5

Lo•om

  • A loom is a device used to weave cloth. The basic purpose of any loom is to hold the warp threads under tension to facilitate the interweaving of the weft threads.
  • The precise shape of the loom and its mechanics may vary, but the basic function is the same.2.5

Hai•ku

  • A form of Zen poetry, characterized by being three lines: two contrasting ideas with a connecting point.
  • Haiku is brief and compressed, it suggests rather than explains.2.5

Each conceptual thread is tied to a haiku taken from the cautionary and empowering statements made by community activists from the high Andes.

The haiku are visualized with photographs taken in each community’s context and woven together with threads of archival images of glaciers in the Peruvian Andes taken in the 1920’s.

The quotes and photographs come together create a patterned fabric that invites contemplation of the topic and its relationship to ecological resilience.2.5

Eco•lo•gy

  • A branch of science concerned with the interrelationship of organisms and their physical surroundings.
  • The totality or pattern of relations between organisms and their environment.2.5

This expanded documentary project explores humanity’s potential to be resilient amidst extreme drought conditions and unprecedented ecological change through the warp and weft of empowering stories of struggle and transformation.
